newsitem.title: USA: U.S. HEADLINE STOCKS - Issues to watch - Aug 18.
newsitem.headline: U.S. HEADLINE STOCKS - Issues to watch - Aug 18.

text.p: -- Shares in Intel Corp dropped more than half a point in after-hours trading Friday. Dealers blamed catch-up transactions after a major sell-off in the broader market during regular trade. Intel was also off in overnight London trading.

-- Shares in other leading technology stocks, such as International Business Machines Corp and Digital Equipment Corp, were also down in overnight trading, along with other U.S. blue chips, including Philip Morris, Coca-Cola Co, DuPont and Pfizer.
-- British Airways Plc and AMR Corp's American Airline are preparing for the prospect of a scaled-down alliance amid regulatory resistance, the Wall Street Journal reported.
-- Xerox Corp will launch its first household product today -- the Document Home Center, a combination color scanner, printer and copier, the New York Times reported.
-- Cornerstone Properties Inc has agreed to buy 11 properties in six U.S. cities from a Dutch pension fund for $1.06 billion in stock and cash, the Wall Street Journal reported.
-- International Business Machines Corp is set to launch a $90 million advertising campaign for its latest AS/400 computer line, the Wall Street Journal reported.
-- Netscape Communications Corp will introduce a stand-alone version of Navigator, its popular Internet-browser software, the Wall Street Journal said.
-- MAXIMUS Inc said it had won a $26 million contract to provide welfare-to-work services in Milwaukee County beginning September 1.
-- Hudson Foods Inc said the ground beef products associated with last week's meat recall involve sales revenues of less than one percent of the company's total sales.
-- Dart Group Corp said Sunday it had reached a settlement with the Haft family, which founded the company. The deal involves Dart buying shares from family members.
